summary: An email chain from May 2020 discussing an alleged extortion attempt against Mark Epstein, Jeffrey Epstein's brother. The chain includes a forwarded message from an anonymous sender claiming to have information about Jeffrey Epstein's murder and demanding money, which was shared among U.S. Attorney's Office personnel and the FBI.

events.title: Extortion email sent to Mark Epstein
events.description: An anonymous sender emails Mark Epstein claiming to have information about Jeffrey Epstein's murder, demanding money, and alleging a prison guard was paid $6,500 and cameras were tampered with.

events.title: Email chain discussion among officials
events.description: U.S. Attorney's Office personnel and the Office of the Inspector General discuss the forwarded extortion email and consider a conference call.

locations: 1 Battery Park Plaza, 29th floor, New York, NY 10004
keyFacts: Mark Epstein, Jeffrey Epstein's brother, received an anonymous email in May 2020 attempting to extort money by claiming to have information about Jeffrey's murder.
The anonymous email alleges Jeffrey Epstein was strangled by a man in his prison cell, guards were paid $6,500, and prison cameras were tampered with.
Mark Epstein forwarded the email to an FBI agent involved in the death investigation and to his media contacts.
The email chain was subsequently shared among personnel at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York and the Office of the Inspector General.
The anonymous sender claims to be 'police' and states the information could prevent prosecutors and judges from imprisoning Mark Epstein.
